name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRGoatsandSoda: The U.S. will probably have enough doses to vaccinate their population two times over. And Canada will have enough for their population five times over.
  
https://t.co/Mrmhq11lvs

name: NPR
text:
Across Syria, people are facing shortages of subsidized bread — at a time when, for many, it's one of the only foods they can still afford.

Nowadays, people say they're having to wait up to six hours in line for meager rations.
https://t.co/rdU4oImKQG

name: NPR
text:
A Wisconsin court commissioner denied a request to dismiss 2 of the 6 charges facing Kyle Rittenhouse, who is accused of killing 2 people during the Kenosha protests — and ordered the case to go to trial.
https://t.co/NMbpQlLWbV

name: NPR
text: Dr. Francis Collins to his fellow Christians: "When you put on that mask ... You're doing the altruistic, loving thing of saying, 'I'm going to protect people from me.' And that's a Christian action if ever I've heard one." https://t.co/6kmNQLhgXR

name: NPR
text:
RT @maddie_sofia: I've done more than 100 interviews for #NPRShortWave but I think this is the only one I've cried in the middle of. 

Please take the time to listen to what healthcare workers in Nebraska are going through. They don't need hero worship. They need help. 

https://t.co/xr47SB1ZGm

name: NPR
text:
Even in a year like 2020, art can still break through.

For @NPRMusic, these 100 songs were an urgent cacophony of distinct voices — and a silver lining in a collectively awful year.
https://t.co/31EBqn5mY5

name: NPR
text:
Attorney General William Barr said this week that the Justice Department found no evidence of widespread fraud in this year's election. When asked whether he still had confidence in Barr, President Trump said: 

"Ask me that in a number of weeks from now."
https://t.co/hy9NRTAswL

name: NPR
text:
Over the past 20 years, the number of people over 65 who have died as a result of extreme heat has increased more than 50%, a report in the Lancet says. At least 296,000 people died because of heat in 2018.
https://t.co/d1evG9w64P

name: NPR
text:
RT @ElenaMMoore: While the lives of presidential children & grandchildren have historically been kept mostly private, Biden's granddaughters and Harris' stepchildren have formed their own public personas

They’re on Twitter, Instagram and TikTok - and some talk politics 

https://t.co/2ySYobuKcU

name: NPR
text:
The Labor Department's monthly jobs report will likely show a sharp slowdown in job growth in November as the pandemic rages. 

"It's not just the restaurant business," a restaurateur says. "Travel, hospitality, leisure, hotels. We're all just in a mess."
 https://t.co/yLzEQmZQmu

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. government says it will issue a paper card reminding people who get the COVID-19 vaccine to follow through with a second dose to complete their immunization. States will also run notification programs.
https://t.co/DlNoESWBQP

name: NPR
text: RT @BobbyAllyn: 200+ Google employees now demanding explanation from executives about why AI scientist @timnitGebru was fired over research paper into the ethics and environment impact of Google's AI systems https://t.co/mLzVGt6DLe

name: NPR
text:
Democratic lawmakers have introduced a joint resolution that would remove the "punishment" clause from the 13th Amendment, which effectively allows incarcerated people to be used as cheap and free labor.
https://t.co/FKKPsdgQ8B

name: NPR
text:
The list of Trump associates who are facing or could face federal charges is long. And more than once, the president has shown he's willing to use his pardon power to pluck a political ally or associate out of legal trouble.
https://t.co/Hiqc3k2OF9

name: NPR
text:
The firing of a leading Black scientist at Google following a dispute over her research into the ethical impacts of AI has reignited concerns about the company's treatment of employees who speak out — particularly people of color.
https://t.co/N4Nc1SEsyk

name: NPR
text:
Pennsylvania's health secretary says it could be autumn of 2021 before there are enough vaccines for distribution to the general public.

"This is not a quick fix," she said. "We all have to work together and stand united to stop the spread of this virus."
https://t.co/rcffGt1niE

name: NPR
text:
At least a million died fighting for racial and economic equity in the Mexican Revolution. Revolutionaries like Emiliano Zapata used guns. 

But Diego Rivera, José Clemente Orozco, and David Alfaro Siqueiros — "Los Tres Grandes" — fought tyranny with art. https://t.co/p4T00Znj4D

name: NPR
text:
Many New York City nurses worry about staffing shortages as the number of COVID-19 patients grows, saying hospitals haven't done enough to apply lessons learned last spring.

One hospital has about 476 nursing vacancies, according to a union spokeswoman.
https://t.co/mvy3Opy1Kz

name: NPR
text:
Rhode Island's surge in COVID-19 cases has doctors worried the state might not have enough medical workers to treat all the hospitalized people.
 https://t.co/6e7QFvyHYK

name: NPR
text:
Americans For The Arts, the U.S.'s largest arts advocacy group, responded to criticism over its lack of diversity, saying the steps they've taken toward racial and cultural equity "have not been enough."
https://t.co/oKvDqph7cD

name: NPR
text:
U.S. Surgeon General Jerome Adams: "I feel confident that when we have the [emergency use authorization] approved for a vaccine, we will get these vaccines out into the states very quickly."
https://t.co/bfAOOpMgGB

name: NPR
text:
Winter resorts have spent months developing safety protocols for the new ski season — including requiring masks and distancing and having guests to reserve their time on the slopes.
https://t.co/hjFe5RDJ2U

name: NPR
text: Every Warner Brothers movie released in 2021 will be available to stream on HBO Max the same day it comes out in theaters. https://t.co/nCgriDDgFF

name: NPR
text:
Experts say low-risk people in the U.S. will likely be immunized before many high-risk people in poor countries. "Part of the reason is that rich countries are hoarding the vaccine supply."

These charts show how much vaccine each country has claimed:
https://t.co/bjYkC26FUd

name: NPR
text:
Thousands of Yazidis who were displaced by ISIS fighters have returned to Iraq's Sinjar region, finding homes badly damaged.

"This is our homeland," one woman said. "We would rather live on bread and water here than eat meat and rice as displaced people."
https://t.co/SbcF0cn1Vi
